introduction: The world continued to battle the COVID-19 pandemic and most of our employees continue to work from home.
We successfully combined Mellanox into NVIDIA while delivering a very strong quarter.
Revenue was $3.87 billion, up 50% year-on-year, up 26% sequentially and well ahead of our outlook.
gaming: Gaming revenue was $1.65 billion, up 26% year-on-year and 24% sequentially, significantly ahead of our expectations.
The upside is broad-based across geographic regions, products and channels.
Gaming’s growth amid the pandemic highlights gaming as a leading form of entertainment worldwide.
Daily gamers on Steam are up 25% from pre-pandemic levels.
NPD reported U.S. consumer spending on video games grew 30% in Q2 CY, reaching a record $11 billion.
NVIDIA’s PCs and laptops are ideal for people working, learning, and gaming at home.
As the quarter progressed and stores reopened, retail demand picked up, iCafes reopened, and online sales thrived.
Gaming laptop demand is very strong for work, learn, and gaming from home.
Over 100 new models launched with OEM partners, addressing premium and mainstream price points.
We brought ray tracing to laptops at $999 with GeForce RTX 2060, and to the mainstream segment at $699 with GeForce GTX.
Momentum continues for Turing architecture, enabling stunning new visual effects and driving a powerful upgrade cycle.
RTX technology (ray tracing and AI) has redefined the standard for computer graphics.
DLSS uses AI to boost frame rates by ~2x while maintaining crisp image quality.
RTX adoption continues with titles like DEATH STRANDING, Cyberpunk 2077, and Watch Dogs.
We are running a 21-day countdown to a GeForce special event on September 1.
GeForce NOW (GFN) cloud gaming service is in its second quarter of commercial availability.
GFN offers the richest content via partnerships with major digital stores, letting users play the games they own from the cloud.
GFN is now supported on Chromebooks, expanding reach further.
GFN is available or coming soon through telecom partners worldwide.
pro_vis: Pro Vis revenue was $203 million, down 30% YoY and 34% QoQ.
Declines in both mobile and desktop workstations due to lower enterprise demand and office closures.
Enterprise shift to remote work drove demand for virtual/cloud-based graphics solutions.
Q2 vGPU bookings accelerated, increasing 60% YoY.
Despite challenges, we’re winning new business in healthcare (Siemens, Philips, GE) and public sector.
Over 50 leading design and creative applications are now NVIDIA RTX-enabled.
The pandemic impacts how we work, and revenue mix may shift more to laptops, virtual workstations, and remote collaboration tools.
automotive: Automotive revenue was $111 million, down 47% YoY and 28% QoQ, slightly better than expected.
Impact of the pandemic was less pronounced than anticipated; auto production volumes started to recover.
Legacy infotainment revenue roll-off remains a headwind.
In June, we announced a landmark partnership with Mercedes-Benz for software-defined intelligent vehicles starting in 2024.
This deal uses our full technology stack: DRIVE AGX computer, DRIVE AV software, and AI infrastructure.
Centralizing and unifying computing in the car enables easier integration and over-the-air updates.
This transforms vehicles into high-performance data centers on wheels and positions NVIDIA for recurring revenue streams.
data_center: Data Center revenue was $1.75 billion, up 167% YoY and 54% QoQ.
A full quarter of Mellanox contribution: ~14% of company revenue, over 30% of data center revenue.
Compute and networking set records with accelerating growth.
Launched the Ampere architecture with the A100 GPU, a major technological feat amid the pandemic.
The A100 has 54 billion transistors and supports full NVIDIA software stack.
A100 delivers a 20x AI performance boost over its predecessor.
It’s our first universal accelerator for training, inference, analytics, HPC, and more.
A100 widely adopted by server vendors and CSPs; Google Cloud was first to bring it to market.
Azure announced massively scalable AI clusters with A100 and Mellanox InfiniBand.
A100 coming to AWS, Alibaba Cloud, Baidu Cloud, Tencent Cloud, and over 50 server offerings.
Adoption is faster than any prior launch: 30 systems expected this summer and over 40 more by year-end.
A100 set 16 records in MLPerf 0.7 training benchmarks.
NVIDIA has consistently led in MLPerf training and inference benchmarks.
On the TOP500 list, 8 of the world’s top 10 supercomputers use NVIDIA GPUs/networking.
NVIDIA + Mellanox now power two-thirds of the TOP500, up from less than half two years ago.
Systems with NVIDIA GPUs are more efficient, averaging 2.8x more performance per watt.
NVIDIA’s own Selene supercomputer debuted at #7 on the TOP500, built in under 4 weeks using DGX SuperPOD architecture.
We brought GPU acceleration to data analytics with the latest version of Apache Spark.
Now have 1 billion cumulative CUDA GPUs shipped and 2 million developers in our ecosystem.
mellanox: Mellanox delivered fantastic results in its first quarter as part of NVIDIA.
Revenue growth accelerated with strength in Ethernet and InfiniBand.
Major hyperscale builds drove upside as AI and cloud fueling demand for high-performance networking.
Mellanox networking critical in DGX systems, DGX SuperPOD clusters, EGX Edge AI platform.
Launched Mellanox ConnectX-6 Ethernet NIC and acquired Cumulus Networks to enhance software-defined data centers.
financials: Q2 GAAP gross margin was 58.8%, non-GAAP gross margin was 66%.
GAAP gross margin declined due to Mellanox acquisition costs.
Non-GAAP gross margin up ~6 points YoY due to higher data center mix, lower auto.
Q2 GAAP operating expenses: $1.62 billion, Non-GAAP: $1.04 billion.
GAAP OpEx up 67% YoY, Non-GAAP up 38% YoY.
GAAP EPS: $0.99, up 10% YoY, Non-GAAP EPS: $2.18, up 76% YoY.
Q2 cash flow from operations: $1.57 billion.
q3_outlook: For Q3 FY2021, revenue expected to be $4.4 billion ±2%.
Gaming expected up just over 25% sequentially.
Data center expected up low to mid-single-digits sequentially.
Pro Vis and Auto expected at similar levels to Q2.
GAAP OpEx: ~$1.54 billion, Non-GAAP OpEx: ~$1.09 billion.
Full-year OpEx tracking in line with prior outlook ($5.7B GAAP, $4.1B Non-GAAP).
